citation.article-title: Actinoplanes capillaceus sp. nov., a new species of the genus Actinoplanes

p.s: Description of Actinoplanes capillaceus sp. nov.
Actinoplanes capillaceus (ca. pi. lla' ceus. L. adj. capillaceus, of capillary, referring to the hairy surface of the spore vesicle)
Aerobic actinomycete which produces extremely branched substrate hyphae which carry bell-shaped spore vesicles (5–10 μm x 5–15 μm) on short sporangiophores.
The surfaces of the spore vesicles are covered by short hairs.Mature spore vesicles release motile spores (0.7–0.8 μm x 2–3 μm) which have polar flagella.
Pink to yellow colored colonies are formed on yeast-starch agar.
Neither soluble nor melanoid pigments are produced.
The organism does not grow in the presence of 3% NaCl, is sensitive to streptomycin (50 μg/ml) but is not inhibited by novobiocin (20 μg/ml).
Additional phenotypic properties are shown in Tables 3 and 4.
The organism has been isolated from soil.
